Presenting Problem / Chief Complaint: The patient is curious about managing stress better during unexpected situations, particularly when facing deadlines for school or work.
History of Present Illness (HPI): The patient has been struggling with motivation in studies but is setting small, achievable goals. They have shown interest in counseling techniques and have been practicing active listening in volunteer work. They also mentioned trying deep breathing techniques to manage stress but sometimes forget to use them.
Mental Health Observations: The patient reports feeling more energized and in control due to regular walks and improved sleep.
Physiological Observations: The patient has been aiming for an earlier bedtime and feels they are sleeping better.
Current Functional Status: The patient has been studying more consistently and is applying learned skills in real-life situations.
Progress Evaluation: The patient is making positive changes in their routine and is actively working on stress management techniques.
Therapeutic Interventions: The patient is encouraged to set reminders for practicing deep breathing and to incorporate it into their walking routine.
Next Steps: The patient will try to make deep breathing a daily habit and report back on their progress.
